actions.title: Securing the Southern Border and Resumption of Border Wall Construction
actions.description: Directs DHS to resume border wall construction, deploy additional Border Patrol agents, and reinstate the Remain in Mexico policy. Declares a national emergency at the southern border to unlock military construction funding and establishes defense restricted military zones.

actions.title: Executive Order Ending Birthright Citizenship
actions.description: Attempts to end birthright citizenship guaranteed by the 14th Amendment for children born in the U.S. to undocumented parents or those on temporary visas. Multiple federal courts issued injunctions blocking enforcement. The Supreme Court ruled 6-3 in Casa that nationwide injunctions are limited but did not rule on the merits.

actions.title: Alien Enemies Act Proclamation
actions.description: Secretly signed March 14, invokes the 1798 Alien Enemies Act to authorize deportation of Venezuelans alleged to be members of Tren de Aragua gang to CECOT prison in El Salvador. Multiple federal courts ruled the invocation illegal, finding that gang activity does not constitute an 'invasion' or 'predatory incursion' within the meaning of the Act. 250+ men deported to CECOT.

actions.title: Sanctuary Jurisdictions Executive Order
actions.description: Targets so-called sanctuary cities and states by threatening to withhold federal funding. Directs the Attorney General and DHS to take enforcement action against jurisdictions that limit cooperation with ICE. Illinois AG challenged the crackdown.

actions.title: Travel Bans on 12 Countries and Expanded Restrictions
actions.description: Full travel ban on nationals from Afghanistan, Burma, Chad, Congo, Equatorial Guinea, Eritrea, Haiti, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan and Yemen. Partial bans on 7 additional countries. 36 more countries given 60-day benchmarks. December: visa suspension for citizens of 75 countries.

actions.title: Termination of Temporary Protected Status for Venezuelans and Haitians
actions.description: Administration moved to terminate TPS for Venezuelans and later Haitians, Hondurans, Nicaraguans, and Nepalese. Courts issued multiple injunctions blocking terminations. The Supreme Court stayed the initial injunction 8-1, but other courts subsequently blocked terminations for additional nationalities.

actions.title: CHNV Categorical Parole Program Termination
actions.description: Ended categorical parole programs for nationals of Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua, and Venezuela (CHNV), as well as Uniting for Ukraine (U4U) and Operation Allies Welcome for Afghans. Affecting 500,000+ noncitizens. Supreme Court ruled 7-2 to stay injunctions blocking the terminations.

actions.title: H-1B Visa Fee Proclamation ($100,000)
actions.description: Imposes a $100,000 fee on new H-1B visa applicants, using Sections 212(f) and 215(a) of the INA. Triggered split between MAGA allies favoring immigration restrictions and tech entrepreneurs relying on H-1B workers. U.S. Chamber of Commerce filed legal challenge calling the action ultra vires.

actions.title: Refugee Admissions Suspension and Caps
actions.description: Suspends the U.S. Refugee Admissions Program and drastically reduces refugee admissions caps. Follows pattern from first term of limiting humanitarian pathways into the United States.

actions.title: Harvard Foreign Student Visa Ban
actions.description: Bans foreign students from obtaining visas to study at Harvard University, part of broader conflict with universities over DEI and government funding conditions. Student visa revocations exceeded 100,000 under Trump 2.0 before the government reversed some F-1 registration reversals.

actions.title: Withdrawal from Paris Climate Agreement
actions.description: Orders U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement (effective in one year) under the UNFCCC. Revokes the U.S. International Climate Finance Plan. Administration considering full withdrawal from the UNFCCC treaty itself, which would be unprecedented.

actions.title: National Energy Emergency Declaration
actions.description: Declares a national energy emergency and orders withdrawal of all Outer Continental Shelf areas from offshore leasing review. Focuses on expanding exploration and production on federal lands and waters, rare earth minerals, and accelerating permitting.

actions.title: Unleashing American Energy Executive Order
actions.description: Eliminates EV subsidies, pauses IRA and Infrastructure Act disbursements for EV charging, resumes LNG export permits, mandates revision of regulations burdening domestic mining. Revokes multiple Biden-era climate and energy EOs.

actions.title: Climate Change Data Purge and Scientist Dismissals
actions.description: Dismissed ~400 scientists contributing to the National Climate Assessment (NCA6). Purged climate data from government websites. Barred U.S. scientists from IPCC meetings. Halted U.S. contributions to UNFCCC. Dismantled State Department's Office of Global Change. DOE expanded banned words list to include 'climate change,' 'sustainability,' and 'emissions.'

actions.title: Department of Agriculture Climate Policy and Data Removal
actions.description: Removal of climate-related policies, guides, datasets and resources from USDA websites. Challenge filed by farmers organization, NRDC, and Environmental Working Group represented by Earthjustice.

actions.title: Ending Radical and Wasteful Government DEI Programs (EO 14151)
actions.description: Orders termination of all federal DEI programs and equity-related grants and contracts. Requires contractors to certify they do not operate DEI programs. Blocked by federal judge on First and Fifth Amendment grounds with a nationwide preliminary injunction, later stayed by Fourth Circuit pending appeal.

actions.title: Ending Illegal Discrimination and Restoring Merit-Based Opportunity (EO 14173)
actions.description: Companion to EO 14151 targeting private sector DEI. Requires certification and threatens DOJ enforcement against private companies. EEOC sent letters to 20 law firms seeking information about employment practices including DEI, citing Title VII.

actions.title: Gender Identity Executive Orders
actions.description: Multiple orders addressing gender identity in federal policy, including defining sex as binary, restricting transgender military service, and rolling back protections for transgender individuals in federal programs and facilities.
agencies: Department of Health and Human Services

actions.title: Restoring Truth and Sanity to American History (Museums EO)
actions.description: Targets national parks and museums including the Smithsonian Institution, claiming they promote divisive ideology. Led to removal of Trump impeachment references from exhibits, removal of first woman director of National Portrait Gallery, and White House review of museum content and curatorial processes.

actions.title: Eliminating Disparate Impact Liability
actions.description: Executive order targeting disparate impact theory in civil rights enforcement, rolling back longstanding approach to identifying systemic discrimination in employment, housing, and lending practices.
agencies: Department of Housing and Urban Development

actions.title: Federal Hiring Freeze
actions.description: Imposes a broad hiring freeze across the federal government with limited exceptions for military and national security positions. Part of broader effort to reduce federal workforce size.

actions.title: Schedule F Reclassification of Federal Employees
actions.description: Reclassifies tens of thousands of federal employees from career civil service to at-will 'Schedule F' (now 'Schedule Policy/Career') positions, stripping job protections and enabling political loyalty tests. Fulfills the vision articulated by Vance in 2021 to 'fire every single midlevel bureaucrat.'

actions.title: Creation of DOGE (Department of Government Efficiency)
actions.description: Renames the U.S. Digital Service as DOGE, led by Elon Musk. Initially tasked with tech modernization, expanded to dismantling agencies, halting programs, firing employees, and accessing sensitive data systems. Partnership for Public Service estimated DOGE cuts cost taxpayers $135 billion. Only 35% of Americans approve.

actions.title: USAID Shutdown
actions.description: Effective shutdown of USAID with 4,200+ employees placed on leave. Multiple courts found the closure likely violated the Constitution. DOGE-led effort to dismantle the agency on an accelerated basis. Five former USAID Administrators from both parties spoke out against the closure. Foreign aid frozen, then partially restored by courts.

actions.title: Dismantling the CFPB
actions.description: Efforts to shut down the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which was created after the 2008 financial crisis. Judge Amy Berman Jackson found the government was 'fully engaged in a hurried effort to dismantle and disable the agency entirely' in disregard of Congress's 15-year-old mandate. Preliminary injunction granted.

actions.title: Dismantling the Department of Education
actions.description: Ordered reduction in force covering 2,000 employees (nearly half the workforce). Judge Joun issued preliminary injunction, finding the government's 'true intention is to effectively dismantle the Department without an authorizing statute.' Supreme Court later granted administrative stay 6-3, allowing dismantling to proceed.

actions.title: Federal Employee 'Fork in the Road' Buyout Directive
actions.description: OPM offered federal employees buyout packages to resign, framed as a 'fork in the road.' Courts declined to block the buyouts on standing grounds, allowing Trump to close the offers. Underlying legality remains untested.

actions.title: DOGE Workforce Optimization and Mass Firings
actions.description: DOGE-led mass terminations of probationary employees across multiple agencies. MSPB granted 45-day stays on dismissals at agencies including USDA (5,000+ employees). DOGE accessed sensitive personnel systems including Treasury's payment systems and student loan data for 42 million borrowers.

actions.title: Rescission of 78 Biden Executive Orders
actions.description: Rescinded 78 Biden EOs on Day One, including those advancing racial equality, combating gender discrimination, addressing climate change, imposing ethics requirements for appointees, lowering prescription drugs, protecting transgender persons in the military, and imposing sanctions on settlers accused of violence against Palestinians.

actions.title: Tariffs on China, Mexico, Canada, and EU
actions.description: Imposed sweeping tariffs including on Chinese goods, Mexican and Canadian imports, and EU products. Goldman Sachs predicted tariffs would impair labor markets, trigger higher inflation and slow growth. Consumers absorbed 22% of tariff costs through June, projected to absorb 67% if trends continue.

actions.title: Sovereign Wealth Fund Executive Order
actions.description: Directs the Treasury Secretary and Commerce Secretary to develop a plan for establishing a U.S. sovereign wealth fund. Details and implementation timeline remain unclear.

actions.title: Defense Contractors Executive Order
actions.description: Prohibits underperforming defense contractors from stock buybacks or dividends. Requires executive compensation tied to on-time delivery and production metrics rather than short-term financial metrics. Directs SEC to consider amending Rule 10b-18 safe harbor for buybacks.

actions.title: SNAP Benefits Funding Disruption
actions.description: USDA suspended all November 2025 SNAP benefits for 42 million people despite $6 billion in available appropriated contingency funds. Multiple courts ordered full payment. Judge McConnell found the administration was 'withholding full SNAP benefits for political purposes' constituting 'unjustifiable partisanship.'

actions.title: Pocket Rescission of Appropriated Funds
actions.description: House voted 216-213 to rescind $9 billion in previously allocated funds including $7 billion in foreign aid and $1.1 billion for Corporation for Public Broadcasting. Senate approved 51-48. Uses the Impoundment Control Act. Additional rescission votes threatened.

actions.title: January 6 Pardons
actions.description: Pardoned participants in the January 6, 2021 Capitol attack, including those convicted of violent offenses. Undermines accountability for the insurrection and sends signal about consequences for political violence.

actions.title: Addressing Risks from Perkins Coie (Law Firm EO)
actions.description: Targets Perkins Coie for its work as counsel to the Clinton campaign. Suspends security clearances, requires government contractors to disclose business with the firm, directs EEOC to review practices of 'large, influential law firms.' Part of broader campaign targeting six law firms through EOs.

actions.title: Executive Orders Targeting WilmerHale, Jenner & Block, and Susman Godfrey
actions.description: Targeted law firms for having employed members of the Mueller investigation team or for representing clients disfavored by Trump. Susman Godfrey was targeted for a $3,000-$4,999 donation to LGBTQ advocacy group GLAD. Courts ruled the EOs unconstitutional, violating First Amendment rights. All told, law firm pro bono commitments to the White House totalled $940 million.

actions.title: Presidential Memorandum on Abuses of the Legal System
actions.description: Directs AG to seek sanctions against attorneys engaging in 'frivolous litigation against the United States,' particularly immigration lawyers. Raises possibility of further security clearance suspensions and contract terminations. Calls for review of attorney conduct over the past eight years. Characterized as an attack on 'the very foundations of our legal system.'

actions.title: Strengthening and Unleashing America's Law Enforcement
actions.description: Encourages increased arrests and incarceration even for minor offenses, increases militarized equipment in policing, reduces accountability for misconduct, provides indemnification for officers. Directs military assets for crime prevention. DoJ attorneys removed from New Orleans Police Department consent decree.

actions.title: Withdrawal from the World Health Organization
actions.description: Orders U.S. withdrawal from the WHO, pauses all financial support, and recalls U.S. government personnel and contractors. Rescinds the 2024 U.S. Global Health Security Strategy, which had identified climate change as a health security risk.
agencies: Department of Health and Human Services

actions.title: CDC Purges and Public Health Data Removal
actions.description: Purged federal websites including CDC datasets and webpages containing public health data. CDC could lose up to 10% of its workforce. Drastic cutbacks at NOAA and NWS impact weather forecasting and climate data used by the public, emergency responders, and developing countries.
agencies: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Department of Health and Human Services

actions.title: Teacher Quality and SEED Grant Terminations
actions.description: Terminated grants under the Teacher Quality Partnership Program, SEED Grant Program, and Teacher and School Leader Incentive Programs. Multiple courts issued temporary restraining orders. Supreme Court vacated one TRO 5-4 but other injunctions remain. Southern Education Foundation grants also terminated and restored by court.

actions.title: Preserving and Protecting Elections (Voter ID/Proof of Citizenship)
actions.description: Requires proof of citizenship to vote and prevents states from accepting mail-in ballots after election day. The President lacks constitutional authority over election rules. 146 million Americans lack valid passports. Republicans are less likely to have passports than Democrats. SAVE Act passed the House requiring in-person citizenship proof.

actions.title: Foreign Aid Funding Freeze
actions.description: Secretary Rubio issued stop-work order January 24 freezing all foreign aid. Courts found the government violated the separation of powers by declining to spend congressionally appropriated funds. Judge Ali ordered nearly $2 billion in payments. Supreme Court restored the order 5-4 after Chief Justice Roberts' temporary stay. D.C. Circuit found the government 'has given no justification to displace the bedrock expectation that Congress's appropriations must be followed.'

actions.title: ICC Sanctions and UN Withdrawal Actions
actions.description: Imposes sanctions on International Criminal Court officials. Moves to withdraw from various UN bodies and agreements. Halted financial contributions to UNFCCC ($13.3 million). Will not send official delegation to COP30 in Brazil.

actions.title: Unleashing Alaska's Resource Potential
actions.description: Targets restrictions on resource development on State and Federal lands in Alaska implemented by the previous administration. Part of broader energy and resource development agenda.

actions.title: Third-Country Deportations Without Due Process
actions.description: DHS policy of deporting noncitizens to countries they have no connection to (e.g., Cuba to South Sudan, Guatemala to Mexico) without providing notice or opportunity to contest removal. Judge Murphy found the government acted 'unquestionably in violation' of his court order. Supreme Court ultimately stayed his injunction 6-3.

actions.title: White House Press Pool Takeover and Media Attacks
actions.description: White House announced it would select media outlets for the presidential press pool, replacing the century-old White House Correspondents' Association system. Barred Associated Press from the Oval Office. FCC chair ordered investigation into NPR and PBS. Attacked and effectively silenced Voice of America, Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, and Radio Free Asia.

actions.title: Restoring Freedom of Speech (Content Moderation EO)
actions.description: Described by Catherine Rampell as 'the start of an Orwellian effort to root out wrongthink from government ranks and the private sector.' Part of broader censorship effort targeting content moderation while simultaneously purging government information from websites.

actions.title: Corporation for Public Broadcasting Defunding
actions.description: CPB received $1.1 billion cut in rescission package. Administration attempted to fire CPB Board members despite lacking legal authority. CPB sued seeking declaratory relief. Approximately 1,000 member stations, particularly those in rural areas and serving Native Americans, face shutdown. Harris Poll found 66% of Americans support federal funding for public radio.

actions.title: Corporation for Public Broadcasting Dissolution
actions.description: The CPB board voted unanimously to dissolve after 58 years, following Congress's rescission of all federal funding in July 2025. The dissolution affects 1,500+ local public TV and radio stations, with rural and tribal stations losing more than half their budgets. Pending litigation was dismissed as moot.

actions.title: Operation Metro Surge â€” 2,000 ICE Agents Deployed to Minneapolis
actions.description: DHS expanded Operation Metro Surge on January 6, deploying 2,000 federal agents to Minneapolis-St. Paul. The operation resulted in 3,000+ arrests and two U.S. citizen deaths: Renee Good (shot by ICE officer Jonathan Ross on Jan 7) and Alex Pretti (shot by CBP officers on Jan 24). DHS admitted agents lied under oath about compliance with court orders. Operation ended February 12 following nationwide protests in 300+ cities and litigation by the Minnesota AG.

actions.title: Withdrawal from 66 International Organizations
actions.description: Presidential Memorandum directing withdrawal from 66 international organizations, including 31 UN entities and 35 non-UN bodies. Notable targets include the IPCC, UNFCCC, UN Women, UN Population Fund, and the International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance. Follows earlier withdrawals from WHO, Paris Climate Agreement, and the UN Human Rights Council.

actions.title: DOJ Criminal Investigation of Fed Chair Powell
actions.description: The DOJ, through U.S. Attorney Jeanine Pirro (D.C.), opened a criminal investigation of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell and served the Fed with grand jury subpoenas. The probe focuses on Powell's Senate testimony regarding Fed headquarters renovation costs but is widely seen as political retaliation for Powell refusing to lower interest rates at Trump's demand. This is the first criminal investigation of a sitting Fed Chair in the central bank's 113-year history.

actions.title: Section 232 Critical Minerals Action
actions.description: Presidential Proclamation implementing Section 232 national security findings on processed critical minerals and derivative products. No immediate tariffs imposed; the President directed the Secretary of Commerce and USTR to negotiate agreements to reduce U.S. reliance on foreign mineral sources, with a 180-day deadline (July 13, 2026). Tariffs remain a possibility if negotiations fail.
agencies: Office of the U.S. Trade Representative

actions.title: FBI Raid on Washington Post Reporter's Home
actions.description: FBI agents searched the home of Washington Post reporter Hannah Natanson and seized her phone, two laptops, a recorder, a portable hard drive, and a Garmin watch. The search was connected to an investigation of a Pentagon contractor. A federal judge later scolded the DOJ for failing to inform him of the Privacy Protection Act of 1980, which protects journalists from government searches unless they are themselves under investigation. Natanson is not under investigation.

actions.title: Cuba Oil Supplier Tariffs (IEEPA)
actions.description: Executive order declaring Cuba a 'national emergency' under IEEPA and imposing tariffs on any country delivering oil to Cuba. The tariffs were effectively invalidated on February 20 when the Supreme Court ruled 6-3 that IEEPA does not authorize tariff imposition. Trump signed a new EO eliminating the tariffs but maintaining the national emergency designation.

actions.title: Federal Charges Against Journalist Don Lemon
actions.description: DOJ indicted journalist Don Lemon and 8 co-defendants on charges of conspiracy against religious freedom and interfering with the exercise of religious freedom at a place of worship. The charges stem from Lemon's livestreaming coverage of an anti-ICE protest at Cities Church in St. Paul on January 18, where demonstrators entered after discovering a pastor was an ICE official. Lemon was arrested by FBI/HSI in Beverly Hills at midnight, released on own recognizance, and pleaded not guilty. Career prosecutors reportedly refused to participate in the case.

actions.title: Schedule F Final Rule (Schedule Policy/Career)
actions.description: OPM published the final rule for 'Schedule Policy/Career' (formerly Schedule F), reclassifying approximately 50,000 federal employees in policy-influencing positions as at-will workers. Reclassified employees lose civil service protections, cannot appeal suspensions, demotions, or firings to the MSPB, and cannot challenge their reclassification. The rule received 40,000+ public comments, 94% opposed. Effective March 8, 2026. AFGE, AFSCME, and AFL-CIO have all filed lawsuits.

actions.title: EPA Endangerment Finding Revocation
actions.description: EPA finalized the rescission of the 2009 Greenhouse Gas Endangerment Finding, which had been the legal foundation for all federal climate regulation for 16 years. The finding had determined that greenhouse gas emissions endanger public health and welfare. The revocation also repealed emissions standards for light-, medium-, and heavy-duty vehicles. Multiple lawsuits were immediately filed by environmental and public health organizations.

actions.title: Pentagon Purge of Senior Military Leaders (Expanded)
actions.description: Defense Secretary Hegseth continued and expanded his purge of senior military leadership, firing or forcing out dozens of additional officers in February 2026 including Lt. Gen. Joe McGee, Col. Dave Butler, and Adm. Alvin Holsey (SOUTHCOM commander, who resigned over civilian strikes). Hegseth ordered a 20% reduction in four-star general officers. Five former defense secretaries, including Trump's own Jim Mattis, condemned the firings as 'reckless.' This extends the earlier purge of Gen. CQ Brown, Adm. Franchetti, and Gen. Slife.

actions.title: Section 122 Global Tariff (Post-IEEPA Replacement)
actions.description: Within hours of the SCOTUS IEEPA ruling, Trump signed a proclamation imposing a 10% global tariff under Section 122 of the Trade Act of 1974, citing 'fundamental international payment problems.' The rate was hiked to 15% the following day. Section 122 has never before been invoked and is limited to 150 days without Congressional approval, with a statutory cap of 15%. Effective February 24, 2026.
agencies: Office of the U.S. Trade Representative

actions.title: CIA Retracts 19 Intelligence Reports for 'Political Bias'
actions.description: CIA Director John Ratcliffe ordered the retraction or revision of 19 intelligence reports after Trump's Intelligence Advisory Board identified them as exhibiting 'political bias.' Topics included LGBT activists in the Middle East, women and white violent extremism, and contraception during COVID-19. Of the 19 reports, 17 were permanently deleted and 2 were revised and re-released. Senate Intelligence Committee ranking member Mark Warner called it 'politicization' of intelligence.
agencies: Office of the Director of National Intelligence

actions.title: SCOTUS Allows Third-Country Deportations (6-3)
actions.description: The Supreme Court ruled 6-3 to lift a lower court order that had required the government to give deportees 10 days' notice and an opportunity to raise fear-based claims before being deported to countries they have no connection to. Deportees have been sent to South Sudan, Libya, and Saudi Arabia. Justice Sotomayor's dissent accused the majority of 'rewarding lawlessness' by allowing the administration to violate due process rights.

actions.title: SCOTUS Strikes Down IEEPA Tariffs (6-3)
actions.description: The Supreme Court ruled 6-3 in Learning Resources, Inc. v. Trump that IEEPA does not authorize the president to impose tariffs, finding that tariff power is 'very clearly a branch of the taxing power' reserved to Congress under Article I. The ruling invalidated all tariffs imposed under IEEPA, including the 'trafficking tariffs' on China, Canada, and Mexico. Over $130 billion in tariffs had been collected under IEEPA authority.

pushback.title: CASA v. Trump - Birthright Citizenship Challenge (Supreme Court)
pushback.description: Multiple challenges to the birthright citizenship EO consolidated at the Supreme Court. The Court ruled 6-3 that nationwide injunctions are limited but did not rule on the merits of the EO. Three district courts and the Ninth Circuit found the EO unconstitutional under the 14th Amendment. Class certifications granted. Case on the merits accepted by Supreme Court.
pushback.court: U.S. Supreme Court
pushback.outcome: Nationwide injunctions limited; lower courts continue blocking EO on merits; Supreme Court accepted merits appeal

pushback.title: Washington v. Trump - Birthright Citizenship Injunction
pushback.description: State of Washington, joined by other states, challenged the birthright citizenship EO. District Judge Coughenour granted a preliminary injunction. Ninth Circuit affirmed 2-1, ruling the EO is unconstitutional under the 14th Amendment - the first appellate court ruling on the merits.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, Western District of Washington / Ninth Circuit
pushback.outcome: Ninth Circuit affirmed injunction; EO found unconstitutional under 14th Amendment

pushback.title: J.G.G. et al. - Alien Enemies Act Challenge (D.C. Circuit)
pushback.description: ACLU and Democracy Forward challenged the Alien Enemies Act proclamation. Chief Judge Boasberg issued TROs blocking deportations, found probable cause for criminal contempt of government officials. Administration deported 250+ men to CECOT while court proceedings were ongoing. D.C. Circuit vacated contempt finding but allowed proceedings to continue. Full court declined en banc review 8-3.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Columbia / D.C. Circuit
pushback.outcome: Multiple TROs issued; deportees exchanged for political prisoners; contempt proceedings ongoing

pushback.title: Abrego Garcia v. Trump - Wrongful Deportation to CECOT
pushback.description: Salvadoran national with protective legal status wrongfully deported to CECOT prison due to 'administrative error.' Supreme Court unanimously ordered government to 'facilitate' his return. Fourth Circuit Judge Wilkinson warned the government was 'asserting a right to stash away residents in foreign prisons without due process.' Eventually returned and charged with smuggling in apparent retaliation. Judge granted habeas corpus and ordered release from ICE custody.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Maryland / Fourth Circuit / Supreme Court
pushback.outcome: Supreme Court ordered return; government complied after months of litigation; vindictive prosecution investigation underway

pushback.title: J.A.V., J.G.G., W.G.H. - Alien Enemies Act (Southern District of Texas)
pushback.description: First ruling on the merits of the Alien Enemies Act invocation. Trump-appointed Judge Rodriguez ruled the use illegal, finding that gang activity does not constitute 'invasion' or 'predatory incursion' within the statute's meaning. The historical record 'renders clear' the invocation 'exceeds the scope of the statute.'
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, Southern District of Texas
pushback.outcome: Alien Enemies Act invocation declared illegal; class action certified

pushback.title: A.A.R.P. et al. - Alien Enemies Act (Supreme Court Stay)
pushback.description: Emergency application to Supreme Court for stay of removal. Supreme Court ordered 7-2 that no putative class members be removed pending further order. Fifth Circuit on remand ruled 2-1 that the Alien Enemies Act was improperly invoked. En banc hearing underway. Government asked during oral arguments whether Beatles 'British Invasion' would qualify - answer: yes.
pushback.court: U.S. Supreme Court / Fifth Circuit
pushback.outcome: Supreme Court stay in effect; Fifth Circuit ruled against government; en banc hearing pending

pushback.title: National TPS Alliance v. Trump - Venezuelan/Haitian TPS
pushback.description: Challenge to termination of TPS for Venezuelans and Haitians. District Judge Chen granted motion to delay the agency action. Ninth Circuit denied government's emergency appeal. Supreme Court stayed the order 8-1 (Jackson dissenting). Separate rulings blocked termination of Nepalese, Honduran, and Nicaraguan TPS.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, Northern District of California / Ninth Circuit / Supreme Court
pushback.outcome: Supreme Court stayed lower court order; additional TPS terminations blocked by other courts

pushback.title: National TPS Alliance - Nepalese, Honduran, Nicaraguan TPS
pushback.description: District Judge Thompson granted postponement of TPS terminations for Nepal, Honduras, and Nicaragua. Court found DHS Secretary Noem was motivated by 'animus against immigrants' and that her statements 'perpetuate the discriminatory belief that certain immigrant populations will replace the white population.' Affects 60,000 people.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, Northern District of California
pushback.outcome: Postponement granted; hearing on merits scheduled

pushback.title: CHNV Parole Program Challenge
pushback.description: Challenge to termination of categorical parole programs for CHNV nationals and Ukrainian/Afghan refugees. Judge Talwani granted class certification and stay. Government appealed; First Circuit denied stay. Supreme Court ruled 7-2 to stay the injunction, lifting block on parole terminations affecting 500,000+ noncitizens.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Massachusetts / First Circuit / Supreme Court
pushback.outcome: Supreme Court stayed injunction; parole terminations proceeding

pushback.title: U.S. Chamber of Commerce v. Trump - H-1B Visa Fees
pushback.description: First action the U.S. Chamber of Commerce has brought against the Trump administration this term. Argues the $100,000 H-1B fee is ultra vires, exceeding authority under the INA, and violates the Administrative Procedures Act. In FY 2024, approximately 400,000 H-1B applications were approved.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court

pushback.title: NADOE v. Trump - DEI Executive Orders Challenge
pushback.description: Challenge to both DEI EOs (14151 and 14173). Judge Abelson issued a nationwide preliminary injunction on First and Fifth Amendment grounds covering terminations of equity-related grants, DEI certification requirements, and DOJ enforcement threats. Fourth Circuit later stayed the injunction pending appeal.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Maryland / Fourth Circuit
plaintiffs: Mayor and City Council of Baltimore
pushback.outcome: Nationwide preliminary injunction granted; stayed by Fourth Circuit pending appeal

pushback.title: AFL-CIO v. DOGE - Data Access Challenge
pushback.description: AFL-CIO and various unions sued to halt DOGE access to Department of Labor, HHS, and CFPB systems. Judge Bates declined preliminary injunction for lack of irreparable harm but left door open for merits case, stating the court's 'concerns are as grave as ever' and 'by no means green-lights DOGE Affiliates' access to Americans' most sensitive information.'
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Columbia
pushback.outcome: Preliminary injunction denied; case proceeding on merits

pushback.title: AFSA/AFGE v. Trump - USAID Shutdown Challenge
pushback.description: American Foreign Service Association and AFGE challenged the USAID shutdown. Judge Nichols denied preliminary injunction but Judge Chuang found DOGE closure 'likely violated the Constitution' and ordered reinstatement of access and halt to further dismantling. Five former USAID Administrators from both parties issued joint statement in support.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Columbia / D.C. Circuit
pushback.outcome: Mixed results; DOGE closure found likely unconstitutional by one judge; litigation ongoing

pushback.title: DOGE Employees v. USAID - Accelerated Closure
pushback.description: 26 USAID employees and contractors sued DOGE over accelerated closure. Judge Chuang granted preliminary injunction finding DOGE closure 'likely violated the Constitution,' ordering reinstatement of email access, halt to further shutdown actions, and steps to allow USAID to reoccupy premises. Warned violations subject to contempt.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Maryland
pushback.outcome: Preliminary injunction granted; DOGE closure found likely unconstitutional

pushback.title: NTEU v. CFPB - Consumer Bureau Dismantling
pushback.description: National Treasury Employees Union challenged CFPB dismantling. Judge Amy Berman Jackson granted preliminary injunction, finding the government was 'fully engaged in a hurried effort to dismantle and disable the agency entirely' in 'complete disregard' of Congress's 15-year-old mandate. Bar complaints filed against three DOJ attorneys for misrepresentations.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Columbia
pushback.outcome: Preliminary injunction granted blocking dismantling

pushback.title: New York v. McMahon - Department of Education Dismantling
pushback.description: 20 states and D.C. challenged the unconstitutional dismantling of the Department of Education. Judge Joun found government's 'true intention is to effectively dismantle the Department without an authorizing statute.' Granted preliminary injunction and ordered RIF employees reinstated. Supreme Court granted administrative stay 6-3, allowing dismantling to resume.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Massachusetts / First Circuit / Supreme Court
pushback.outcome: Injunction granted then stayed by Supreme Court 6-3; dismantling resumed

pushback.title: Southern Education Foundation - Grant Termination
pushback.description: Challenge to termination of federal grants to the Southern Education Foundation, founded in 1867 to advance equitable education after the Civil War. Judge Friedman granted preliminary injunction halting the termination of grants for EAC-South, a technical assistance center addressing effects of desegregation.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Columbia
pushback.outcome: Preliminary injunction granted

pushback.title: AFGE v. OPM - Federal Employee Buyout Challenge
pushback.description: AFGE and other unions challenged the 'Fork Directive' buyout offers. Judge O'Toole declined to block the buyouts, finding unions lacked standing and court lacked jurisdiction. While a setback, the underlying legality of the buyout offers remains untested.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Massachusetts
pushback.outcome: Dismissed on standing; legality of buyouts untested

pushback.title: University of California v. Department of Education - DOGE Data Access
pushback.description: University of California Student Association sued over DOGE illegally accessing sensitive personal and financial information of approximately 42 million federal student loan borrowers.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court

pushback.title: 22 States v. USDA - SNAP Benefits Funding
pushback.description: 22 states, D.C., and multiple organizations challenged USDA's suspension of SNAP benefits for 42 million Americans despite available funds. Judge McConnell ordered full payment, finding the administration was 'withholding full SNAP benefits for political purposes' - 'unjustifiable partisanship.' Supreme Court Justice Jackson granted administrative stay pending First Circuit appeal.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Rhode Island / First Circuit
plaintiffs: Rhode Island State Council of Churches
pushback.outcome: Courts ordered full payment; administrative stay pending appeal

pushback.title: CPB v. Trump - Corporation for Public Broadcasting
pushback.description: CPB sued seeking declaratory relief that the President's attempted termination of CPB Board members has no legal effect, as the President lacks authority to remove CPB Board members. CPB represented by Saul Ewing.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court

pushback.title: Perkins Coie v. Trump - Law Firm EO Challenge
pushback.description: Perkins Coie challenged the EO targeting the firm. Judge Beryl Howell ruled in favor of the firm. Administration appealed the ruling. DoJ revoked security clearances despite temporary restraining order. The EO's retaliatory intent described as 'unmistakable' by the court.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Columbia
pushback.outcome: Injunction granted; government appealed

pushback.title: WilmerHale v. Trump - Law Firm EO Challenge
pushback.description: WilmerHale challenged the EO targeting the firm for welcoming back members of the Mueller investigation team. Temporary restraining order issued. DoJ revoked security clearances despite the order. Administration has not appealed the ruling in favor of WilmerHale.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court
pushback.outcome: Restraining order issued; security clearances revoked in defiance

pushback.title: Jenner & Block v. Trump - Law Firm EO Challenge
pushback.description: Jenner & Block challenged the EO targeting the firm for having employed a former Mueller team federal prosecutor. Temporary restraining order issued. DoJ revoked security clearances despite the order. Administration appealed the ruling.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court
pushback.outcome: Restraining order issued; government appealed

pushback.title: Susman Godfrey v. Trump - Law Firm EO Challenge
pushback.description: Susman Godfrey challenged the EO targeting it, allegedly for a $3,000-$4,999 donation to LGBTQ advocacy group GLAD. Judge Alikhan granted summary judgment and permanent injunction, finding the EO 'violates the Constitution and the laws of the United States, and threatens the independence of the bar.' Court found no statutory or constitutional basis for targeting a law firm for its choice of clients or donations.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Columbia
pushback.outcome: Summary judgment and permanent injunction granted; EO found unconstitutional

pushback.title: California et al. v. Department of Education - Teacher Grants
pushback.description: 8 states sued over termination of Teacher Quality Partnership and SEED grants. Judge Joun granted TRO. Government appealed to First Circuit (denied) then to Supreme Court, which vacated the TRO 5-4. Separate challenge by AACTE and others resulted in another TRO from Judge Rubin.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Massachusetts / First Circuit / Supreme Court
pushback.outcome: Initial TRO vacated by Supreme Court 5-4; other injunctions remain

pushback.title: AACTE v. Department of Education - SEED/TQP/TSL Grants
pushback.description: American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education challenged termination of SEED, TQP, and TSL grants. Judge Rubin granted TRO on Administrative Procedures Act grounds. Appeal pending in Fourth Circuit.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Maryland / Fourth Circuit
plaintiffs: American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education
pushback.outcome: TRO granted; appeal pending

pushback.title: Global Health Council v. State Department - Foreign Aid Freeze
pushback.description: Challenge to the freeze on foreign assistance funds. Judge Ali issued TROs and ordered nearly $2 billion in payments. Supreme Court vacated the initial administrative stay 5-4, restoring the payment order. D.C. Circuit found the government violated the Appropriations Clause. Judge Ali ordered payments for work performed before February 3.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Columbia / D.C. Circuit / Supreme Court
plaintiffs: Small Business Association for International Companies
pushback.outcome: Nearly $2 billion in payments ordered; Supreme Court restored order 5-4

pushback.title: D.C. Circuit - Foreign Aid Impoundment Ruling
pushback.description: D.C. Circuit ruled that the government violated the separation of powers by declining to spend congressionally appropriated foreign aid funds. Found the government 'has given no justification to displace the bedrock expectation that Congress's appropriations must be followed' and the government 'remain under a duty to comply with the appropriations laws.'
pushback.court: U.S. Court of Appeals, D.C. Circuit
pushback.outcome: Government ordered to comply with appropriations laws

pushback.title: D.V.D. et al. - Third-Country Deportation Challenge
pushback.description: Class action challenging DHS policy of deporting noncitizens to countries they have no connection to. Judge Murphy granted TRO and preliminary injunction. Found government acted 'unquestionably in violation' when it attempted to fly deportees to South Sudan. Supreme Court ultimately stayed the injunction 6-3, enabling deportation to South Sudan.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, Northern District of Ohio / Supreme Court
pushback.outcome: Injunction stayed by Supreme Court 6-3; deportees sent to South Sudan

pushback.title: Associated Press v. Trump - Press Pool Exclusion
pushback.description: AP sued after being barred from the Oval Office and Air Force One for declining to call the Gulf of Mexico the 'Gulf of America.' WHCA president characterized the move as 'tearing at the independence of a free press.' Fox News correspondent criticized it as giving 'power to the White House.'
pushback.court: U.S. District Court

pushback.title: CPB v. Trump - Board Member Terminations
pushback.description: Corporation for Public Broadcasting sued seeking declaratory relief that the President's attempted termination of CPB Board members is of no legal effect given the President has no power to remove or terminate CPB Board members.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court

pushback.title: Nationwide Class Certification - Birthright Citizenship (Post-Casa)
pushback.description: After the Supreme Court's Casa ruling limiting nationwide injunctions, Judge Laplante granted nationwide class certification and preliminary injunction for all persons born after Feb 20, 2025 affected by the birthright EO. Judge Sorokin ruled his initial injunction remained valid under a Casa exception. Three courts blocked the EO after Casa.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of New Hampshire
pushback.outcome: Nationwide class certified; preliminary injunction issued; EO remains blocked

pushback.title: Defense Restricted Zones - Trespass Charges Dismissed
pushback.description: Chief Magistrate Judge Wormuth dismissed nearly 100 trespass charges against undocumented migrants in defense restricted military zones in New Mexico, finding the government failed to show migrants knew they entered restricted zones. Migrants could still be deported for illegal entry.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of New Mexico
pushback.outcome: Nearly 100 charges dismissed

pushback.title: Climate Scientists/Advocacy Groups - NCA Dismissals
pushback.description: Union of Concerned Scientists and environmental groups challenged the dismissal of ~400 NCA scientists, the purging of climate data, and the banning of scientists from IPCC meetings. Multiple government agencies barred from using terms like 'climate change' and 'sustainability.'
pushback.court: Various

pushback.title: Farmers/NRDC v. USDA - Climate Data Removal
pushback.description: Farmers organization, NRDC, and Environmental Working Group sued USDA over removal of climate-related policies, guides, datasets and resources from websites. Represented by Earthjustice and Knight First Amendment Institute at Columbia University.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court

pushback.title: CPSC Commissioners v. Trump - Removal Challenge
pushback.description: Three Biden-appointed CPSC commissioners challenged their termination. Judge Maddox granted summary judgment in their favor, finding they could only be removed for cause. Fourth Circuit denied stay. Supreme Court granted emergency stay citing Trump v. Wilcox, allowing the firings to proceed.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Maryland / Fourth Circuit / Supreme Court
pushback.outcome: Supreme Court granted emergency stay allowing firings

pushback.title: CIA/ODNI Officers - Termination Challenge
pushback.description: 51 career intelligence officers assigned to DEIA personnel management functions sued CIA and ODNI. Judge Trenga refused to halt the firings, citing that all plaintiffs were at-will employees.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, Eastern District of Virginia
pushback.outcome: Dismissed; at-will employees not protected

pushback.title: Guatemalan Children - Emergency Deportation Block
pushback.description: Emergency challenge to deportation of 10 unaccompanied minors aged 10-17. Filed at 1 AM, judge called at 2:36 AM, order issued at 4 AM blocking removals. One plane with children took off and was returned. Children protected under the 2008 Trafficking Victims Protection Law. Sen. Wyden detailed plans to remove ~700 Guatemalan children.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Columbia
pushback.outcome: Emergency TRO granted at 4 AM; children returned to ORR custody

pushback.title: Violence Against Women Act Grants Challenge
pushback.description: 17 anti-domestic violence coalitions challenged DOJ requirements that Violence Against Women Act grantees certify they do not promote 'gender ideology,' run DEI programs or prioritize undocumented immigrants. Judge Smith granted preliminary injunction based on violation of APA prohibition against 'arbitrary and capricious agency action.'
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Rhode Island
pushback.outcome: Preliminary injunction granted; grant conditions found to violate APA

pushback.title: Erez Reuveni - DOJ Whistleblower Complaint
pushback.description: Former acting Deputy Director of DOJ's Office of Immigration Litigation filed formal whistleblower complaint detailing DOJ and White House violations of law. Revealed that Principal ADAG Bove suggested telling courts 'fuck you' and ignoring court orders regarding deportation flights. Reuveni was suspended and fired for telling the truth to courts.
pushback.court: DOJ Office of Inspector General
pushback.outcome: Complaint filed; allegations of obstruction of justice by senior DOJ officials

pushback.title: State Attorneys General Coalition - Multi-Front Pushback
pushback.description: 23 Blue state AGs and D.C. regularly challenging the administration on multiple fronts: federal funding suspensions, privacy rights violations, tariffs, machine gun conversions, abortion access restrictions, and voter data demands. Individual AGs like CA challenged Marine deployments and IL challenged sanctuary city crackdowns.
pushback.court: Various Federal Courts
pushback.outcome: Ongoing multi-front litigation; numerous injunctions obtained

pushback.title: Trump v. New York Times - Defamation Suit (Dismissed)
pushback.description: Trump sued the New York Times, Random House and various journalists for $15 billion in defamation. Judge Merryday struck the complaint under Rule 8, calling it 'decidedly improper and impermissible' and stating 'a complaint is not a public forum for vituperation and invective.' Trump refiled the case.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, Middle District of Florida
pushback.outcome: Complaint struck; refiled

pushback.title: Trump v. CNN - Defamation Suit (Dismissed)
pushback.description: Eleventh Circuit affirmed dismissal of Trump's defamation suit against CNN over use of the phrase 'Big Lie.' Court found statements were opinion, not actionable factual claims, and Trump failed to plead actual malice.
pushback.court: U.S. Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit
pushback.outcome: Dismissal affirmed on appeal

pushback.title: Fifth Circuit - Alien Enemies Act Ruled Improper (En Banc)
pushback.description: Fifth Circuit panel ruled 2-1 that the Alien Enemies Act was improperly invoked, finding conditions for invocation (invasion or predatory incursion by a foreign nation) were not met. Government's absurd position that even the Beatles' 'British Invasion' would qualify was highlighted. Full en banc hearing underway.
pushback.court: U.S. Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit
pushback.outcome: Panel ruled against government; en banc hearing pending

pushback.title: Learning Resources, Inc. v. Trump â€” SCOTUS Strikes Down IEEPA Tariffs
pushback.description: The Supreme Court ruled 6-3 (Roberts writing, Thomas/Kavanaugh/Alito dissenting) that IEEPA does not authorize tariffs, finding the taxing power is reserved to Congress under Article I. The ruling invalidated all tariffs imposed under IEEPA authority, affecting over $130 billion in collected tariffs. The administration imposed replacement tariffs under Section 122 within hours.
pushback.court: U.S. Supreme Court
pushback.outcome: IEEPA tariffs struck down; replacement tariffs imposed under Section 122

pushback.title: Minnesota v. Noem â€” Operation Metro Surge Challenge
pushback.description: Minnesota Attorney General filed suit against DHS Secretary Noem over Operation Metro Surge after two U.S. citizens (Renee Good and Alex Pretti) were killed by federal agents. ICE violated 96+ court orders in January alone. The suit alleges systematic violations of the Fourth Amendment, due process rights, and the Posse Comitatus Act. The City of Minneapolis joined as co-plaintiff.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Minnesota
pushback.outcome: Pending; operation ended February 12

pushback.title: Provinzino Contempt Order â€” ICE Court Order Violations
pushback.description: Judge Provinzino held a DOJ attorney in civil contempt with $500/day fines after ICE violated 96 court orders in Minnesota in a single month. The DOJ attorney admitted the order 'fell through the cracks.' This was the first civil contempt finding against a government attorney in the immigration enforcement context. Contempt was lifted after compliance.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Minnesota
pushback.outcome: Civil contempt finding; $500/day fines imposed then lifted after compliance

pushback.title: Boasberg Return Order â€” Venezuelan CECOT Deportees
pushback.description: Chief Judge Boasberg ordered the return of 137 Venezuelans deported to CECOT under the Alien Enemies Act, citing 'flagrant' due process violations. The government was ordered to pay for return flights. The administration has not complied and is appealing.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Columbia
pushback.outcome: Return ordered; government appealing; noncompliance ongoing

pushback.title: US v. Comey & US v. James â€” Fourth Circuit Appeal
pushback.description: DOJ appealed the dismissals of cases against former FBI Director James Comey and NY AG Letitia James after trial courts found prosecutor Lindsey Halligan was unlawfully appointed. Cases consolidated on appeal to the Fourth Circuit. Comey was charged with false statements; James with mortgage fraud. Both cases are widely seen as politically motivated.
pushback.court: U.S. Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit
pushback.outcome: Appeal pending; unlawful appointment finding under review

pushback.title: Grand Jury Refuses to Indict Democratic Lawmakers
pushback.description: A grand jury unanimously refused to indict six Democratic lawmakers including Sens. Mark Kelly and Elissa Slotkin on seditious conspiracy charges sought by the DOJ over a 90-second video encouraging military members to disobey unlawful orders. Part of an unprecedented pattern of grand jury losses for the administration's politically-motivated prosecution efforts.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Columbia
pushback.outcome: Indictment refused; DOJ cannot re-present to same grand jury

pushback.title: In re Natanson â€” Washington Post Reporter Raid Challenge
pushback.description: Washington Post filed an emergency motion after FBI raided reporter Hannah Natanson's home and seized all electronic devices. The judge rebuked the DOJ for failing to disclose the Privacy Protection Act of 1980, which protects journalists from government searches unless they are themselves targets. A preliminary injunction was granted ordering return of devices and restricting review of seized materials.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Columbia
pushback.outcome: Preliminary injunction granted; DOJ rebuked for PPA violation

pushback.title: United States v. Lemon â€” First Amendment Church Protest Charges
pushback.description: Don Lemon pleaded not guilty to charges of conspiracy against religious freedom and interfering with the exercise of religious freedom at a place of worship. This was the government's fourth attempt at charges after three courts refused warrants. Career prosecutors reportedly refused to participate. Press freedom organizations including FIRE, CPJ, and PEN America condemned the prosecution as a First Amendment violation.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Minnesota
pushback.outcome: Not guilty plea entered; First Amendment challenge expected

pushback.title: NTEU v. Vought â€” CFPB En Banc Rehearing
pushback.description: D.C. Circuit granted en banc rehearing, vacating the panel decision that had allowed CFPB dismantling. Preliminary injunction reinstated blocking mass layoffs. CFPB ordered to request Federal Reserve funding as required by statute. Oral arguments scheduled for February 24, 2026.
pushback.court: U.S. Court of Appeals, D.C. Circuit (en banc)
pushback.outcome: En banc granted; preliminary injunction reinstated; oral arguments Feb 24

pushback.title: AFGE v. OPM â€” Government Shutdown RIF Litigation
pushback.description: Judge Illston blocked RIF actions during the government shutdown, finding employees could not be lawfully terminated while the government was not operating. Hundreds of layoffs were reversed. Congress passed a moratorium on federal layoffs through February 13, which has since expired.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, Northern District of California
pushback.outcome: Layoffs reversed; moratorium expired Feb 13

pushback.title: AFGE & AFSCME v. OPM â€” Schedule F Challenge
pushback.description: Multiple unions filed lawsuits challenging the Schedule F final rule. AFGE, AFSCME, NARFE, and Democracy Forward/PEER all have pending cases. A preliminary injunction reinstated collective bargaining rights. Summary judgment motions pending. The final rule takes effect March 8, 2026, and would affect 50,000+ employees.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Columbia
pushback.outcome: Preliminary injunction on collective bargaining; summary judgment pending

pushback.title: Earthjustice et al. v. EPA â€” Endangerment Finding Repeal
pushback.description: Earthjustice, Clean Air Task Force, and environmental organizations challenged EPA's rescission of the 2009 Greenhouse Gas Endangerment Finding. The lawsuit argues the revocation violates the Clean Air Act and is arbitrary and capricious. Case expected to reach the Supreme Court given its implications for all federal climate regulation.
pushback.court: U.S. Court of Appeals, D.C. Circuit
pushback.outcome: Filed; expedited briefing requested

pushback.title: New York v. ACF â€” Child Care Funding Freeze
pushback.description: New York and other states challenged the freezing of $10 billion in child care funds across CCDF, TANF, and Social Services Block Grants targeting five blue states. Judge Broderick granted a preliminary injunction, ordering the release of frozen funds.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, Southern District of New York
pushback.outcome: Preliminary injunction granted; frozen funds ordered released

pushback.title: Rhode Island et al. v. HHS â€” Transgender Funding Conditions
pushback.description: 12 state attorneys general challenged $300+ billion in HHS grants conditioned on binary sex definitions, effectively barring funding for transgender health services. Three prior injunctions from other courts have been ignored by HHS. Rhode Island AG leads the coalition.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Rhode Island
pushback.outcome: Filed; seeking preliminary injunction

pushback.title: LULAC v. Executive Office â€” Election EO Permanently Struck Down
pushback.description: Federal judge permanently struck down multiple core provisions of Trump's election executive order, including proof-of-citizenship requirements for voter registration, voting machine mandates, and late ballot prohibitions. The court found the President lacks constitutional authority over election rules, which are reserved to Congress and the states.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Columbia
pushback.outcome: Permanent injunction; multiple provisions declared unconstitutional

pushback.title: New England Synod v. DHS â€” Church Raids Injunction
pushback.description: Churches including Baptist, Lutheran, and MCC congregations obtained an injunction establishing a 100-foot buffer zone around houses of worship, prohibiting ICE checkpoints near churches, and barring arrests inside churches during services. The court found the raids violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act and the First Amendment.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Massachusetts
pushback.outcome: Injunction granted; 100-foot buffer zone established

pushback.title: USAID Employees v. Musk â€” Deposition Ordered
pushback.description: Judge Chuang rejected Elon Musk's apex doctrine defense and ordered Musk, Marocco, and Lewin all deposed under oath regarding DOGE's role in the USAID dismantlement. The ruling found Musk had unique personal knowledge of DOGE's decision-making process that could not be obtained through other witnesses.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Maryland
pushback.outcome: Musk deposition ordered; apex doctrine rejected

pushback.title: 23 State AGs v. OMB â€” Federal Funding Freeze
pushback.description: 23 state attorneys general and D.C. filed suit over the rescission of $11 billion in federal health grants targeting blue states. Judge Shah blocked the rescissions, and Judge McConnell blocked the broader general funding freeze. Multiple overlapping suits address different aspects of the administration's funding withholding strategy.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, Northern District of Illinois
pushback.outcome: Multiple injunctions blocking funding rescissions

pushback.title: New York v. McMahon â€” Education Department Amended Complaint
pushback.description: 21 state attorneys general filed an amended complaint in the Education Department dismantling case, adding new allegations regarding IAA transfers of student loan servicing, K-12 funding cuts, vocational training elimination, and that the department dismissed 90% of civil rights complaints. The original lawsuit obtained injunctions that were later stayed by the Supreme Court 6-3.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court, District of Massachusetts
pushback.outcome: Amended complaint filed with expanded allegations

pushback.title: CPB Board Dissolution â€” Congressional Defunding Consequences
pushback.description: CPB's board voted unanimously to dissolve after Congress rescinded all federal funding. The earlier litigation (CPB v. Trump over board member firings) was dismissed as moot after CPB and the Trump administration filed a joint status report. The 58-year-old institution ceased operations, ending federal support for 1,500+ local public broadcasting stations.
pushback.court: U.S. District Court
pushback.outcome: Prior litigation mooted; organization dissolved
